The 'Dichotomy of Control,' a core Stoic principle taught by Epictetus, instructs individuals to focus only on what they can influence, a technique now fundamental to modern Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT).
Aaron T. Beck, the founder of CBT, explicitly cited Stoic philosophy as the primary philosophical precursor to his clinical methods for treating anxiety and depression.
The Stoic practice of 'Premeditatio Malorum,' or the premeditation of evils, involves visualizing worst-case scenarios to diminish the power of anxiety and build psychological preparedness.
Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius wrote 'Meditations' as a private journal for his own mental clarity; it was never intended for publication but has become a foundational text for managing modern stress.
Seneca the Younger famously identified the mechanism of anxiety when he wrote, 'We suffer more often in imagination than in reality,' over 2,000 years ago.
The 'View from Above' is a Stoic exercise used to reduce personal anxiety by mentally zooming out to view one's life in the context of the entire universe, creating a sense of perspective.
Stoics practiced 'Voluntary Discomfort,' such as eating plain food or wearing simple clothing, to prove to themselves that the things they feared losing were not essential for happiness.
Vice Admiral James Stockdale credited the Stoic teachings of Epictetus with giving him the mental resilience to survive seven years of torture and solitary confinement as a POW in Vietnam.
The Stoic concept of 'Amor Fati,' or the love of fate, encourages people to embrace everything that happens as necessary, which helps reduce the anxiety caused by resisting or regretful thinking.
Modern scientific studies on journaling have validated the Stoic habit of daily self-reflection as an effective tool for lowering cortisol levels and improving emotional regulation.
